intro: Lucuma gnaphaloclados, commonly known as the Andean starfruit, is a flowering plant native to the high altitudes of the Andes in South America. It belongs to the family Malvaceae and is characterized by its distinctive star-shaped fruit, which resembles a small star with a yellowish-orange exterior. The plant produces small, hairy leaves and has a woody stem that can grow up to several meters in height. Its fruit is typically harvested when it turns a bright yellow, and it is valued for its sweet, aromatic pulp. Lucuma gnaphaloclados is adapted to cold, high-altitude environments and requires well-drained soil to thrive.
